title: 105_s927
content: The Act is titled the "National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1998" and amends the National Sea Grant College Program Act. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Amends Section 202(a)(1) to encourage the development of forecast and analysis systems for coastal hazards. Amends Section 202(a)(6) to promote activities through Federal support of programs by sea grant colleges and institutes. In Section 203 (33 U.S.C. 1122), amendments are made to clarify terms related to ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources. The term 'field related to ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources' is defined broadly. Additionally, the term 'Great Lakes' now includes Lake Champlain. The term 'Great Lakes' now includes Lake Champlain. The term 'institution' is defined broadly as any public or private institution of higher education, institute, laboratory, or State or local agency. Amendments clarify terms related to ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources, including defining 'project' as any activity in these fields administered by an expert, and 'sea grant college' as any institution or alliance involved in such activities. The term 'sea grant institute' refers to institutions designated by the Secretary under section 207 of the Act. The term 'sea grant program' is a research and outreach program administered by sea grant colleges or institutes. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Commerce. The term 'State' includes various regions of the United States. The Act is amended to replace references to the "Under Secretary" with "Secretary" in various sections. The National Sea Grant College Program under Section 204 (33 U.S.C. 1123) is amended to read as "SEC. 204. NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM." The national sea grant college program, administered by a national sea grant office, consists of financial assistance, sea grant programs, administration, fellowship program, and strategic investments. The Secretary, in consultation with the panel, sea grant colleges, and sea grant institutes, develops a long-range strategic plan for the national sea grant college program and establishes guidelines for their activities and responsibilities. The Secretary establishes guidelines for the activities and responsibilities of sea grant colleges and institutes, including requirements for merit review of proposals and qualifications for designation. The Secretary may appoint personnel and make appointments for the program's provisions. The Secretary may appoint personnel for temporary and intermittent services, publish valuable information related to ocean resources, enter contracts without certain restrictions, accept donations and funds from other federal departments. The Secretary can appoint personnel for temporary services, publish ocean-related information, enter contracts without restrictions, accept funds from other federal departments, and appoint a qualified individual as the Director of the National Sea Grant College Program. The Director must have administrative experience and knowledge in ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources. The Director of the National Sea Grant College Program administers the program under the supervision of the Secretary, oversees the national sea grant office, and facilitates the development of a strategic plan. They also advise the Secretary on available expertise, encourage collaboration with other offices and agencies, and assist in designating sea grant areas. The Director of the National Sea Grant College Program advises the Secretary on designating sea grant colleges and institutes, encourages program growth and cooperation with other federal activities. They evaluate programs, allocate funding to promote competition among colleges and institutes. The National Sea Grant College Program aims to designate colleges and institutes, support program implementation, provide stable funding, and ensure compliance with merit review guidelines. The Sea Grant Program Improvement Act of 1976 is repealed, and Section 207 is amended to address Sea Grant colleges and institutes. Sea grant colleges or institutes must have competence in ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources, commit long-term to objectives, collaborate with others, receive financial assistance, excel in related fields, and meet additional qualifications determined by the Secretary. Sea grant colleges or institutes must meet qualifications set by the Secretary, maintain programs in research, advisory services, training, and education related to ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources. The Secretary may designate institutions or alliances that meet these qualifications as sea grant colleges or institutes. The National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1998 outlines the process for designating sea grant colleges or institutes. Existing designees do not need to reapply if they meet qualifications. The Secretary can suspend or terminate designations for cause. The National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1998 outlines the duties of sea grant colleges and institutes, including developing programs in consultation with the Secretary, and conducting merit reviews of grant proposals. SEC. 8. SEA GRANT REVIEW PANEL. The National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1998 amends Section 209 to update duties and terminology related to sea grant colleges and institutes. The National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1998 updates duties and terminology related to sea grant colleges and institutes, including section 5376 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is provided for grants, contracts, and fellowships under the Act, with specific amounts authorized for fiscal years 1999 to 2003. Additional funding is allocated for zebra mussel and oyster research, including competitive grants for university research on the zebra mussel. Authorization is provided for grants, contracts, and fellowships under the Act, with specific amounts authorized for fiscal years 1999 to 2003. Funding is allocated for research on zebra mussels, oysters, Pfiesteria piscicida, and harmful algal blooms through competitive university grants. A limitation is set on the funding for program elements to ensure proper allocation. Reprogramming actions requiring notice are also addressed. The Secretary of Commerce must provide notice to specific committees before any major reorganization of the National Sea Grant College Program, as outlined in the Act. SEC. 10. ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGES. The United States Coast Guard can perform adjudicatory functions for marine resource conservation laws on a reimbursable basis, as requested.
